chapter.htmlHeader: What is the scale of the problem?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 is increasing daily. This topic will be updated regularly to provide new information as it becomes available in a rapidly changing landscape.
  • However, Johns Hopkins University has provided an interactive map of the spread of this disease on this publically available site, which can be found here.
  • Coronavirus COVID-19 global cases:
    • At the date of publication there were over 85 million cases worldwide, over 1.8 million deaths, and over 50 million people who had been identified as recovered.
    • According to the WHO the case mortality rate (number of reported deaths divided by case reports) appears to be around 3-4%, but the infection mortality rate (number of deaths divided by the number of infections) is lower and is estimated to be around 1%. 
    • The initial outbreak was in mainland China, but transmission is now worldwide.
    • Larger outbreaks in South Korea, Italy, and Iran with varying rates of infection and mortality.
    • There were over 2.6 million confirmed cases in the UK on 4 January 2021, and 75,137 deaths.
    • Public Health England has provided a similar interactive map with UK data which is updated daily at 4pm, which can be found here.
  • A Public Health England report that looked at the disparities in risks and outcomes of COVID-19 has found that in the period reviewed [PHE, 2020a]:
    • The highest age-standardized diagnosis rates of COVID-19 per 100,000 population were in people of Black ethnic groups (486 in females and 649 in males).
    • The lowest were in people of White ethnic groups (220 in females and 224 in males). 
  • An analysis of survival among confirmed COVID-19 cases showed that, after accounting for the effect of sex, age, deprivation, and region: 
    • People of Bangladeshi ethnicity had around twice the risk of death when compared with people of White British ethnicity.
    • People of Chinese, Indian, Pakistani, Other Asian, Caribbean, and Other Black ethnicity had between 10% and 50% higher risk of death than White British people.
  • Compared with this period last year, all-cause mortality was almost 4 times higher than expected among Black males for this period, almost 3 times higher in Asian males and almost 2 times higher in White males. Among females, deaths were almost 3 times higher in this period in Black, Mixed, and Other females, and 2.4 times higher in Asian females than 1.6 times in White females. 
  • However, these analyses did not account for the effect of occupation, comorbidities, or obesity.
